evidences.text: Today we'll talk about three broad frameworks that I will ask you probably to apply on an exam or in some context.
They are consequential frameworks where we're concerned more about the actual outcomes or consequences of a particular action over the course of making a decision.
A duty based framework that is more concerned with an agent's intent rather than the actual consequences of what happens.
And in the virtue based framework, which is more about the ethical makeup of an agent, in my mind, there's a pretty clear line between consequential and duty based.
But duty and virtue kind of make it a harder thing to delineate.
So we see the play between the two, right?
One is emphasizing the caliber of the actions that you take, and the other one is quantifying the results those actions have.
So there's a whole spectrum of different types of ethical ideologies.
And this is one attempt to try to canonize them into a.
There are plenty of other ethical systems even within the categories that we talked about.
Ethical egotism, eudemism, eudaimonism, the ethics of care.
Like I said, my goal here was to give you an introduction to the three basic ones.
But there are plenty of other ones that are interesting that you could explore if you want.
